awd_titl_txt: CIF:Small:Submodular Optimization Techniques for Sensing, Signal Processing, and Inference.
awd_abstract_narration:
A rapidly growing collection of modern systems rely on sensors to collect measurements from which inference is performed via suitably designed signal processing.  These include autonomous vehicles, environmental monitoring systems, smart buildings, security and surveillance systems, air traffic control, and many others.  Moreover,in many of these existing and emerging applications, there are often stringent energy, cost, bandwidth, or other constraints that must be taken into account in the system design. Problems of placement,
scheduling, and functionality of sensors have traditionally been difficult optimization problems.  This research develops the important role that submodular optimization techniques have to play in addressing such problems.  Indeed, while there has been significant development in submodular optimization tools and applications in recent years, a wealth of applications involving sensing, signal processing and inference have yet to be explored.

The research investigates several instances and aspects of these problems, including: optimization of spatial arrays in passive and active sensing systems subject to diverse practical constraints; joint optimization of sensor placement and scheduling for efficient learning of environmental dynamics; optimization of spatial and temporal sensing subject to computational constraints on the associated signal processing for the inference task of interest; development of families of submodular information measures for target applications involving
both high- and low-level inference; development of robust, adaptive, and universal designs for sensing that mitigate the effects of incomplete knowledge of aspects of the system and environment; and optimization of sensing system parameters beyond space and time via weighted selection formulations exploiting submodularity in the absence of convexity.  Each of these investigations involves the development of the required analysis, algorithms, and architectures, guided by contemporary motivating applications.

por.por_cntn:
Modern society is heavily dependent on advanced sensing systems, and emerging applications are requiring increasingly sophisticated capabilities. To meet these needs, this project pursued new approaches to leverage benefits of submodularity to address multi-faceted sensing challenges. In particular, it investigated explicit mathematical structure for (1) a wider set of realistic constraints, including privacy; (2) joint spatio-temporal sensing for dynamical systems; (3) explicitly considering the interplay of information, complex down-stream statistical inference and computational complexity; (4) universal designs and (5) generalizations to (nonconvex) weighted sensing problems.

As one key contribution, we considered the problem of designing sensor arrays. Traditional design techniques are agnostic to prior information about the scene. However, in many applications such priors are available and may be utilized to design more efficient array topologies. We formulated the problem of array geometry design with scene prior as one of finding a sampling configuration that enables efficient inference, which turns out to be a combinatorial optimization problem. While generic combinatorial optimization problems are computationally infeasible, we showed how for array design problems the theory of submodular optimization may be utilized to obtain efficient algorithms that are guaranteed to achieve near-optimum solutions. We leveraged the connection between array design problems and submodular optimization and ported several results of interest. These included efficient methods for designing arrays with constraints on the sensing aperture, as well as arrays respecting combinatorial placement constraints. 

We further extended our results to the design of arrays operating at multiple wavelengths, under two design paradigms. The first design paradigm is optimized for collection of measurements at multiple wavelengths, fusing these together for joint inference over an underlying scene. The second design paradigm is robust, in a sense that it is guaranteed to allow good inference over the scene at any one single wavelength at a time. We quantified inference quality via the D-Bayes optimality criterion and limited the design space by restricting the number of allowed sensors and the positions where these can be placed. We showed that the resulting combinatorial optimization problems are instances of submodular optimization problems, and thus have good approximate solutions by fast greedy algorithms.

More generally, we observed that in a variety of signal processing applications, the objectve function is stochastic, i.e., given as an expectation of functions over a distribution. In practice, we often have only a limited set of samples. The standard approach indirectly optimizes the function by maximizing the empirical average of observed functions. However, this ignores generalization to the true (unknown) distribution. As a further contribution from this project, we developed how to achieve better performance on the actual underlying function by directly optimizing a combination of bias and variance. Algorithmically, we accomplished this by showing how to carry out distributionally robust optimization (DRO) for submodular functions, providing efficient algorithms backed by theoretical guarantees which leverage several novel contributions to the general theory of DRO. We also showed compelling empirical evidence that DRO improves generalization to the unknown stochastic submodular function.

Our investigation also revealed that in many prospective applications, the functions we aim to optimize are not exactly submodular, e.g., when selecting informative sets of samples (measurements) in black-box optimization. Accordingly, we quantified the extent to which submodular optimization techniques extend to such settings, and how the optimization results degrade when the submodularity property is increasingly violated. For example, for minimization, we showed that a classical algorithm used for submodular minimization performs well even for a class of non-submodular functions (called weakly DR-submodular functions). Moreover, we provided the first approximation guarantee for non-submodular minimization. This has broadly expanded the range of applications of submodular minimization techniques.

Among a variety of additional core contributions, the project established a variety of other results on approximately submodular information theoretic loss criteria that are well matched to contemporary signal processing and high-dimensional inference problems.

Finally, the research had significant broader impacts, emphasizing the professional and intellectual development of students at the undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral levels. These included students from groups traditionally underrepresented in science and engineering. Those who have completed their training have gone on to careers in academia and industry, and are contributing in important ways to the further development of the discipline and its applications.
